M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR BREACH OF COVENANT OF QUIET ENJOYMENT (M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant acted as Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law, including the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment codified at G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and the applicable jurisdictional statutes governing the District Court Department, this Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action because the amount in controversy falls within the jurisdictional limits of the Somerville District Court.

G.L. c. 223.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court under G.L. c. 223 because the real property that is the subject of this dispute is located in Somerville, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Somerville.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff invokes the protections of G.L. c. 239, § 8A as background public policy recognizing tenants’ rights to assert landlord violations of law, including breaches of quiet enjoyment, in actions relating to their tenancy.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 95\u2013.proposition: Independent of the Lease language, Massachusetts law implies and/or imposes a covenant of quiet enjoyment in all residential tenancies.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 95\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the nature of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts tenancies. In its statutory analysis, the court explains that the phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar landlord‑tenant term and that ‘[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.’ Although the case involves both statutory and common‑law quiet enjoyment, the court clearly affirms that, independent of lease language, Massachusetts law implies such a covenant in every tenancy, which includes residential tenancies.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 95\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.” (385 Mass. at 101)

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: Independent of the Lease language, Massachusetts law implies and/or imposes a covenant of quiet enjoyment in all residential tenancies.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes an implied obligation arising from the grant of a lease and refers to an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of a *commercial* lease for dental offices, not a residential tenancy. The court does not state that Massachusetts law implies a covenant of quiet enjoyment in all residential tenancies as a categorical rule; instead, it focuses on the landlord’s wrongful interference and overlapping tort and nuisance theories. Thus, it does not affirm the specific, broad residential-tenancy proposition cited.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The defendants contend that the bill is framed solely on a breach of an implied covenant for quiet enjoyment and cannot be maintained. … The bill is not based solely on breach of the implied covenant.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774–75 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover either actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 only tangentially and solely by citing Simon v. Solomon for the fact that treble damages under § 14 may be calculated on contract rent in a subsidized tenancy. It does not describe the statutory damages scheme (actual damages vs. three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus fees and costs), nor does it analyze what a plaintiff is “entitled to recover” under § 14. Accordingly, it does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Recovery by Wideman based on the contract rent does not result in an improper diversion to her of public funds. A private landlord, like Cruz Management, is not shielded from liability to which the landlord would otherwise be exposed merely because a part of its income is derived from Federal subsidy funds. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 110 n.13 (1982) (permitting recovery of treble damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14, calculated on contract rent, where tenant’s rent was subsidized).

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–61 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover either actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, together with reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains the statutory damages scheme. The court states that a lessor who violates § 14 is liable for "actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee," which matches the proposition that the plaintiff may recover either actual damages or three months’ rent (whichever is greater), plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when the landlord, or others whose conduct the landlord has the power to control, substantially interferes with the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises, or when the landlord, having knowledge of a serious interference, fails to take reasonable steps to cure it.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment (constructive eviction) where substantial interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment flows as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, and where the landlord had the right and ability to control the offending conduct. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s control over the noisy lounge and its failure to effectively abate the condition, despite notice and some attempts, renders the landlord responsible for the serious interference with habitability and bars rent recovery.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 396 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 396 Mass. 273, 278–80 (1985)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 396 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when the landlord, or others whose conduct the landlord has the power to control, substantially interferes with the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises, or when the landlord, having knowledge of a serious interference, fails to take reasonable steps to cure it.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 396 Mass.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 396 Mass. 273 (1985), but instead a negligence case against the town of Belmont concerning a parking lot defect and municipal tort liability. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or any doctrine about interference with a tenant’s beneficial use or a landlord’s duty to cure such interferences. Therefore, this opinion does not support the stated proposition regarding the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 396 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "The primary issue in this case is the town’s maintenance of the Claflin Street parking lot. The case was submitted to the jury under a Mounsey instruction: specifically, whether the landowner violated its duty of care by failing to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition for all lawful visitors. Mounsey, supra at 707."

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment, as applied in Massachusetts, protects residential tenants from substantial, persistent disturbances, including noise and conditions that significantly interfere with the ordinary use of the home and the tenant’s health and safety.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not restate the full content of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it expressly relies on and summarizes earlier Massachusetts cases (Simon, Cruz, Darmetko, Dorgan) that held § 14 is violated where landlords, with notice, fail to repair conditions whose natural and probable consequence is interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment and health. Those cited precedents involved serious, persistent habitability problems (e.g., flooding, leaky roofs, failure to keep premises habitable), thereby affirming that the covenant protects residential tenants from substantial, ongoing disturbances that impair ordinary use and health/safety. Al‑Ziab itself focuses on the fault requirement, but in doing so it reaffirms that kind of protection as the scope of § 14.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 784–86 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment, as applied in Massachusetts, protects residential tenants from substantial, persistent disturbances, including noise and conditions that significantly interfere with the ordinary use of the home and the tenant’s health and safety.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment) to severe, persistent code violations that made the apartment unfit for use as a dwelling, holding that the landlord’s failure to repair, once on notice, constituted interference with quiet enjoyment. While the case’s facts involve heat, hot water, and vermin rather than noise, the court’s articulation of the standard—that a landlord violates § 14 when acts or omissions impair the value of the premises as a dwelling—supports the broader proposition that substantial, ongoing disturbances or conditions affecting ordinary use and health/safety are within the protection of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises. … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… it was inevitable that the failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.

Bourne v. Austin, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 738,.raw_text: Bourne v. Austin, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 738, 743–44 (1985)
Bourne v. Austin, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 738,.proposition: Plaintiff is also entitled to reasonable costs and attorney’s fees pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, even though she is currently self‑represented.
Bourne v. Austin, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 738,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bourne v. Austin is a wetlands regulation case under G.L. c. 131, § 40 and related procedural issues; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, attorney’s fees, or the effect of self‑representation on fee awards. There is no discussion anywhere in the text about a plaintiff’s entitlement to reasonable costs or attorney’s fees, let alone in the context of being self‑represented. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition stated.
Bourne v. Austin, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 738,.relevant_excerpt: “This was a complaint brought in the Superior Court under G. L. c. 231A and under the second sentence of the twenty-third paragraph of G. L. c. 131, § 40 … by which the plaintiff town sought to enjoin the defendants from making repairs to a retaining wall… Judgment was entered declaring that the defendants had not violated G. L. c. 131, § 40… The town appealed. We consider its contentions seriatim.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment also constitutes a violation of the implied warranty of habitability and of Massachusetts public policy protecting tenants’ right to a safe and livable home, which further informs the scope and seriousness of the breach.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent and focuses on implied warranty of habitability as derived from sanitary code violations, not on the covenant of quiet enjoyment or Massachusetts public policy as amplifying that covenant. It expressly criticizes the majority’s broader ‘implied warranty of habitability’ concept and proposes a narrower, code-based implied obligation instead. The text does not link breach of quiet enjoyment to breach of the implied warranty or to an overarching public policy right to a safe and livable home, so it does not support the proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: Defendant’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment also constitutes a violation of the implied warranty of habitability and of Massachusetts public policy protecting tenants’ right to a safe and livable home, which further informs the scope and seriousness of the breach.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: The opinion is exclusively about calculation of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability arising from State Sanitary Code violations. It does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, does not equate a breach of quiet enjoyment with a breach of the implied warranty, and does not invoke broader Massachusetts public policy about tenants’ rights beyond referencing the sanitary code framework. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a breach of quiet enjoyment also constitutes a violation of the implied warranty and public policy, or that such linkage informs the scope and seriousness of the breach.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt: “This case returns to us following its remand to the Superior Court for computation by the trial judge of the damages owed to a tenant by his landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability… Under that warranty principle… the judge had awarded damages to the plaintiff McKenna… for violations of the State Sanitary Code… As we emphasized in our earlier opinion, not every defect gives rise to a diminution in rental value… In all cases, however, the trial court is given broad discretion to determine whether defects constitute material breaches of the warranty of habitability.”
